title: Modus-Modal show option for angular
description:

comments:
Hey Ana, one way to go about this is to hook up a `@ViewChild` that references the modal component, and runs the method off of the `nativeElement` property.

HTML:
```html
  <modus-modal #myModal>
  </modus-modal>
```
Component ts:
```ts
@ViewChild('myModal') modal: ElementRef<HTMLModusModalElement>;
this.modal.nativeElement.open();
```
Hi, Thanks, on .ts file is working good, but running on the web browser it says that nativeElement is undefined, maybe I miss something.

Hi @anamarquezz 
My best guess without seeing all of your code is that you are references `this.modal` before it has been defined.

Is this code being run in an `ngOnInit` hook or similar? If not, then it might be that the code is being run before the DOM is rendered and could be the reason you are getting undefined.

2. Upload multiple files and appears an error message
3. Attempt upload again with a valid file, the error message doesn't go away, and the file used in the upload is opening in the browser.

The error message should be cleared when the upload is valid.

![chrome_ZwIPPkwfE2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50131391/201022056-99f55c4d-e594-4504-a7f6-9fcd64bd4a13.gif)

@enowak1031 @egunther39 Can we refine the requirements on the interactions? Do we allow for user to clear error message? I assume it should allow drop regardless. 
@cjwinsor - Add a button that allows the user to "Reset" the error state back to default. Text string should explain what the error is eg. "Multiple files are not allowed. Please try again"



![Image](https://github.com/trimble-oss/modus-web-components/assets/98049598/382e4487-59ed-4481-a2a4-0d5be9f1accd)


The behavior of the reset button for each error state needs to be identified. 

- Multiple files are not allowed. - Remove all files? or Keep the first file and remove all other files?
- You can only upload <count> files - Keep the first <count> files and remove the rest of them?
- File name exceeds length limit: <file name> - Remove the files that fails this validation?
- File exceeds size limit - Remove the files that fails this validation?

Note: Need to understand how the component is used by the consumer. If the consumer displays something like file list panel where they have the file name and delete icon, then it is possible they also highlight the file that failed the validation allowing the user to take appropriate action. In this particular case, when the user clicks the delete icon to remove the multiple files the consumer will call the `removeFile` method and the error state will be reset when there is only one file remaining.

title: Add Open Source Security Foundation Scorecard
description:
This enables the OpenSSF Scorecard GitHub Action to help us ensure the project will continue to follow the open-source best practices or even improve any possible practice to avoid security risks and vulnerabilities.

`Scorecards.yml` file enables the Scorecard action to run on push to main and once a week (important for some checks like contribution check)

REF: https://securityscorecards.dev/

```yml
name: Scorecards supply-chain security

on:
  # Only the default branch is supported.
  branch_protection_rule:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
  schedule:
    - cron: "16 10 * * 6"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions: read-all

jobs:
  analysis:
    name: Scorecards analysis
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      security-events: write
      id-token: write
      contents: read
      actions: read

    steps:
      - name: Clone repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          persist-credentials: false

      - name: Run analysis
        uses: ossf/scorecard-action@v2
        with:
          results_file: results.sarif
          results_format: sarif
          publish_results: true

      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
        with:
          name: SARIF file
          path: results.sarif
          retention-days: 5

      - name: Upload to code-scanning
        uses: github/codeql-action/upload-sarif@v1
        with:
          sarif_file: results.sarif
```

title: Automate Builds for separate Angular output versions
description:
**Describe the solution you'd like**
The Angular components are built out for version 13 but could be useful for versions 13+ as well. Figure out how to handle multiple versions.

~We may consider outputting multiple packages with multiple workspaces:~
~`angular-13-workspace` -> `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-13-components`~
~`angular-14-workspace` -> `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-14-components`~
~etc...~

~This way we can keep the package versions in sync with the web components package like~
~`@trimble-oss/modus-angular-13-components@1.0.9`~
~`@trimble-oss/modus-angular-13-components@1.0.9`~

With a microfrontend use case it seems necessary for these framework integration package versions to be parallel with the web components package since the browser will only register the web components once at a single version

> This idea has changed a bit, check the discussion below

---

**Progress**
- [X] Create new branch `output-target/ng13`. This naming convention can be used to add branch protection rules for all output target branches
- [X] Add branch protection for `output-target/*` that match the protection rules of the default `main` branch
- [X] Upgrade `main`'s Angular output to Angular 14 - [Completed](https://github.com/trimble-oss/modus-web-components/pull/626/files)
- [X] Update `main`'s Angular package config to include the pre-release flag: `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.11-1411` - [Completed](https://github.com/trimble-oss/modus-web-components/pull/626/files)
- [x] Release `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.11-1411`
- [ ] Update `output-target/ng13` to include the pre-release flag: `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.11-1330`
- [ ] Release `@trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.11-1330`
- [ ] Update docs explaining the branching definitions

---

**Questions**
- How should we structure the GitHub actions?
comments:
This seems reasonable to me. My only (minor) issue with it is that the number of directories will increase as the versions of Angular and React increase.

Is there a possibility of managing this through branches?

main - always has the latest React and Angular integration
ng13 - contains the angular 13 components
react18 - contains the react 18 components

Package version naming convention could still be as you have proposed above, or it could be something like:

@trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@1.0.9-1301
Where the pre-release flag indicates the version of angular it is running?

What are your thoughts @ryan-henness-trimble ?

Both of those ideas seem like the best way to go about this. Managing versions through branches and using the pre-release flag seem like it would keep things clean and descriptive. I'm not familiar with the best git practices for this type of thing but it seems like the workflow may look something like this:
1) Make a change to `stencil-workspace` in `main`
2) `npm run build` from `stencil-workspace` in `main`
3) Commit the changes and generated files to `main`
4) Merge `main` into `ng13` (and other version specific branches)
5) Resolve conflicts by keeping modified versions of files on `ng13`
6) `npm run build` from `stencil-workspace` in `ng13`
7) Commit the generated files to `ng13`

That would leave us with a structure like this:
```
        main/
	  + Latest Web Components package config
	  	--> @trimble-oss/modus-web-components@0.1.10
  	  + Latest React package config
	  	--> @trimble-oss/modus-react-components@0.1.10-1702
  	  + Latest Angular package config
	  	--> @trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.10-1410
	
	ng13/
	  + Latest Web Components package config
	  + Latest React package config
	  + Angular v13.3.0 package config
	  	--> @trimble-oss/modus-angular-components@0.1.10-1330
```

I'll dig a bit more into this @leohaughton
Check again in Sprint 63

Update: We now have a build process for Angular 14 and 15... next week we'll look to add Angular 16.
I'm currently working on a GitHub Action to automate the publishing of it.

description:
**Describe the solution you'd like**
Some components require the user to pass in which icon they want to use as a slot. Since they are able to pass any HTML element into the slot that they would like, it may be better to have them pick from our existing icons by passing a string.

This could also be useful for components that have fixed icons but could benefit from dynamic icons.

We would probably want some internal component that will switch out the icons depending on the string passed in.

**Additional context**
For example, instead of this usage
```js
<example-component>
    <svg slot="some-name" />
</example-component>
```

it would be something like this
```js
<example-component icon="some-icon-name" />
```

title: Angular Integration
description:
### Description
Use StencilJS framework integration functionality to generate Angular wrappers and publish them to NPM.

[Stencil Angular Framework Integration](https://stenciljs.com/docs/angular)

### Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Angular wrappers can be automatically generated
- [ ] Angular wrappers can be automatically published as part of the existing build pipeline
~~Generated Angular wrappers should **not** be stored in version control~~
comments:
@ryan-henness-trimble @coliff 

## TLDR

In the process of building the Angular library from the stencil web components, I have found all of the manual steps that need to be done to build the library. We originally agreed that the best approach would be to **generate everything on the fly** in the github action. I haven't actually tried this yet but I have ran into a few obvious hurdles with the **generate everything on the fly** approach.

I think it would be much better use of our time to just accept that we might need to create an angular-workspace inside source control that will store the generated components.

## Details

Here are the steps that need to be performed to build an angular library and publish it to npm (Not in perfect order):

**Bold items would be difficult / time consuming to implement using the "generate on the fly" approach**

1. Install the angularOutputTarget dev dependency
`> npm install @stencil/angular-output-target --save-dev`

2. Update the stencil.config.ts to include:
```ts
angularOutputTarget({
      componentCorePackage: "@trimble-oss/modus-web-components",
      directivesProxyFile: "./angular-workspace/projects/trimble-oss/modus-angular-components/src/lib/stencil-generated/components.ts",
      directivesArrayFile: "./angular-workspace/projects/trimble-oss/modus-angular-components/src/lib/stencil-generated/index.ts",
    })
```

3. Create an angular workspace
`> npx -p @angular/cli ng new angular-workspace --no-create-application`

4.  Create the modus-angular-components library (run from inside the angular workspace)
`> npx -p @angular/cli ng generate library @trimble-oss/modus-angular-components`

**5. Delete the placeholder components and services from the angular library**

6. Build the stencil project (from the stencil project root directory)
`> npm run build`

**7. Import and Export all components into the angular module**

**8. Update tsconfig to disable lib checks. This is required to allow us to extend the stencil HTML elements in Angular**

9. Link the stencil root directory to the angular directory using `npm link`

**10. Bump the angular library version number**

11. Build the angular library:
`> npx ng run @trimble-oss/modus-angular-components:build:production`

12. Publish the angular library:
`> npm publish`

I started wondering yesterday after our talk if this might be too much of a time burner. Sounds like it might be a good idea to just include them in our source control (like you said), as long as we find a good way to let developers know that they are not the source of truth and shouldn't be modified directly

Agreed.

[1] Add Data Table component (barebones)
description:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JwHy6Hqrj5EJY6deM5382STvM4InvV3OTdci4f1b9Ac/edit#

We may want to wrap a third party table library. Implementation details are TBD
comments:
While working on this issue I came up with some thoughts:

As I started to wrap the Simple-Datatables library, I noticed that there's going to be issues with table functionality (paging, searching, filtering, etc.) when we've got more than one page of data. The table's functions only work with the data that is immediately plugged into the table, there is no easy way to hook into backend calls for paging/searching/filtering. 

Since hooking into backend paging/searching/filtering will probably be necessary in most cases, I think the only real functionality we gain from the table library is that the library will lay all of the data out in table headers/rows easily for us. But the downside of having the headers/rows layed out and rendered for us is that it makes it much harder to have custom control over these (for on click events, styling, etc.) The library provides a render argument that allows rendering of whatever you want in the cells, but it does not play nicely with Stenciljs, we're not able to reference any of the components methods unless we query for the component's public methods through the document/shadow dom (the render method injects whatever youre rendering into the dom as a string reference). 

This library works great when we're able to pass the frontend all of the data at once. But when that is not the case for a basic table, I think I would lean toward building it out ourselves so that we have some more control, and it plays nicely with Stencil

title: Accessibility Research
description:
## Bare minimum
- Aria attributes
- Tab index/order (focus)
- Keyboard controls

## Aria attributes
Web Accessibility Initiative, Accessible Rich Internet Applications

WAI-ARIA helps by adding in further semantics that browsers and assistive technologies can recognize and use to let users know what is going on. 

There are three main features:
1. Roles - The role defines what an element is or does. There are different types (document roles, widget roles, landmark roles, etc.) The ones we'll be focusing on for this project are [widget roles](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles#2._widget_roles).
2. Properties - The properties define the parts of an element. (aries-required, arialabelledby, etc.) Here is a list of [aria properties and states that widgets](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/ARIA_Techniques#widget_attributes) use.
3. States - Similar to properties, they describe the state of your widget. Linked above.

One of the questions I had was whether we wanted to have the library consumer pass in all of our WAI-ARIA properties, but it seems like it's going to be a mixed bag. We want to encapsulate as much as we can without hindering the consumer. I think we can set `role`, `state`, and some `properties` internally. One thing I can see the consumer wanting to set is the `label`.

WC essential internal settings:
- role
- aria-checked
- aria-disabled
- aria-hidden, aria-modal
- aria-invalid
- aria-placeholder
- aria-pressed
- aria-readonly
- aria-required
- aria-valuemax
- aria-valuemin
- aria-valuenow
- aria-labelledby (which is used with aria-label?)

WC optional external settings:
- aria-label

## Tab index/order
Tabindex is an HTML attribute that can set an order for focusable elements which allow keyboard focus for non focusable elements and remove focus for a focusable element.

From what I'm seeing, it looks the best practice is to use only values `-1`, and `0`. This is because once you start adding positive integers, it breaks off the DOMs natural tabbing order; tabbing follows the DOMs element layout naturally, and it is best to stick to that if we can.

`tabindex: -1` - Does not allow the user to select with their tab key, but is able to be focused through JS.
`tabindex: 0` - Allows non focusable elements to receive focus.

For the WC, I'm thinking we should set a tabindex of 0 for ones that should be focusable, and then rely on keyboard controls for any further interaction. Let's shy away of using tabbing to interact with the control other than focusing it. 

## Keyboard events
Using Stencil's `Listen()` decorator, we can listen to keyboard events and interact with the component accordingly. Gabe's got a good example in the `modus-select` component.

Using the w3 documentation below.

## Questions
- Does stencil provide a way of setting properties on the host element? This may be useful for our labelling so that the consumer does not need to know best practices, and we can implement it for them. -- Or is this even an issue? There may be good reason to keep everything encapsulated in the ShadowDOM, I have a feeling the DOM cannot access those and relate them.

### Useful links
- W3C has great [documentation for best a11y practices](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices-1.1/#aria_ex) for all types of components that should be reviewed before development.
- Google has some good videos covering all of this
    - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lktz1KXbTOU&t=27s
    - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1D25YXLBBX8
    - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=REVxMvdBYMw
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Accessibility/WAI-ARIA_basics
- https://www.accessibility-developer-guide.com/introduction/
- Chakra UI has some Accessibility built in that I should take a look at
    - https://chakra-ui.com/docs/form/number-input#aria-roles

title: Remove vendor prefixes from scss and use Autoprefixer ?
description:
There are some vendor prefixes in the src/ code which may not be needed (e.g. -webkit-transition and -ms-transform).

It might be better if this was left to Autoprefixer to deal with? I'm not certain though so opening this issue as a discussion.

title: Add Stylelint Config to project
description:
I think we should add stylelint and the stylelint-config-standard-scss config to ensure our CSS is linted and is free of errors and bugs.
https://github.com/stylelint-scss/stylelint-config-standard-scss

I'd be happy to make a PR for this.

title: Update Trimble brand colors
Add Toast component
description: Add the Modus Toast component https://modus.trimble.com/components/toasts/

title: Audit package dependencies
description: The current version of `jest` and `jest-cli` have dependency vulnerabilities. Upgrade their version to clean vulnerabilities.
comments:
maybe consider adding a `.github/dependabot.yml` file to automate update PRs?

```yml
version: 2
updates:
  - package-ecosystem: npm
    directory: "/"
    schedule:
      interval: weekly
    versioning-strategy: increase
  - package-ecosystem: github-actions
    directory: "/"
    schedule:
      interval: weekly
```

title: Navbar main menu
description: Add the main menu (left hamburger) to the navigation component.

title: Add Navigation component right side optional padding
Emit Navbar item click
comments: Not needed.

title: Navbar Reverse Order
description: To support countries that read right to left. The navbar needs to be able to render items in reverse order. This includes fitting panels like user menu, apps menu, etc on the screen in the reverse rendering.

title: Fix label containers for Inputs that do not have labels
description:
Check all components that have containers that only render a single conditional,
fix them so that the container is not rendered if there is no value.

title: Add Slider component
description: Add the Modus Slider component along with its unit and e2e tests.

title: Add Input Date component
description: Add the Modus Input Date component along with its unit and e2e tests.
comments: This component has yet to be defined.

title: Add Message component
description:
Add the Modus Message component along with its unit and e2e tests.

Make sure the component lines up with the Modus Alert component, as they are similar.

title: Navbar responsiveness
description: The navbar needs to conform to the responsive breakpoints in the Modus documentation. This includes things like font-size, spacing (margin and padding), icon sizes, etc.
comments: @coliff and @msankaran0712 Do we have this covered yet in other issues?
hey @enowak1031 I don't think this is covered in any other issue. Please correct me if am wrong @ryan-henness-trimble @coliff
@coliff, I am closing this issue as we now have the logo responsive. We can reopen it if you think anything is missing.

title: Add Radio Button component
description:
Add the Modus Radio button component along with its unit and e2e tests.

We need a parent component that takes a data structure to create all of the radio buttons using functional components. This is because the radio buttons need to know about each other and also be inside the Shadow DOM.

Our first thought was to make the radio buttons composable, but that causes issues with the styles bleeding out into the regular DOM.

title: Navbar - Notifications Menu and Help Menu
description:
Add Notification menu and help menu to the navbar.

Fix the z-index of all menus.

title: Add Switch component
description:
Add the Switch component along with its unit and e2e tests.

https://modus.trimble.com/elements/switches/

title: Navbar app menu (phase 3)
description: Build out a navbar component for the app menu. It should dynamically render apps with logos and clickable links. Following the spec documented on the modus site and figma.

title: Navbar User Menu (phase 2)
description:
Build the navbar user menu, match Figma design.

Provide unit and e2e tests.

title: Add Chip component
description:
Create the Chip component using the Modus Chip specifications.

https://modus.trimble.com/elements/chips/

title: Add Animation Code
description: We skipped adding animations as we built components for multiple reasons. One being, finding the Modus specs for them is really difficult. The other is that it's time consuming. Create a list of components that require animations along with the animation specs.
comments: hey, @coliff does this issue sound familiar to you?
yes, I think we'll add animation CSS with the specs/guidance from the Tiger Team. I'm fine if you close this issue - we can/will add new specific ones once decided exactly what needs to be done.

title: Standardize icon component sizes
description:
Create a shared const for the icon components DEFAULT_SIZE (probably 16).

Reference this instead of hard coded sizes in each icon component.

Check if any other components using the icons are setting the size to 16, if so, remove that code.
comments:
cc @ryan-henness-trimble @coliff 

This issue is not required anymore as we plan to add support for all the Modus Icons and keeping a typescript file for each icon is not an ideal way.

title: Add standard events to Input/Select components
description:
Add standard events to Input and Select components.

Some standard events already work with the Modus components, so they will need to be checked before implementation.

The events that the components should support are:
- onclick
- onfocus
- onblur
comments: @ryan-henness-trimble we can close the issue if it is not needed anymore
Closing this issue as the mentioned events are already handled.

title: Create Navbar Component (phase 1)
description:
Create the Modus Navbar as a web component following [these specs](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/navbar/).

Get the primary nav items on with general layout. Further functionality and responsive design will come later.

Code cover with unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Accordion Component
description:
Create an accordion web component modeled after the Modus accordion element.

Code cover with unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Number Input component
Create Cards Component
description:
Create cards using the latest [Modus spec](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/cards/)

Code cover with unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Breadcrumbs Component
description:
Create breadcrumb per [Modus spec](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/breadcrumbs/)

Code cover with unit and e2e tests.

title: Add Outline Button Style
description: Buttons have a an optional outline style that we didn't build into the original button. Add that style and create a new story to update the Angular site Buttons page.

title: Add Accessibility Code
description:
Make sure than all elements are implementing accessibility attributes properly (will take some research). We may want to expose accessibility properties on our components and let the coder set them, otherwise they'll be too generic.

We forgot to add accessibility code for the following, go do that now (break this story down into smaller ones if needed).

- Alert
- Badge
- Dropdown
- Checkbox
- Text Input
- List Item
- List
- Spinner

title: Cleanup Modus Select
description:
Issues with modus-select:

1. When multiples are visible, both open at the same time.
2. Some clicks still fire when disabled (label, text, arrow, etc). label should never open it

title: Create Modus Dialog Component
description:
Build the modus-dialog component.

Code cover with unit and e2e tests.

title: Cleanup Modus Text Input
description:
Cleanup:
- Scss unneeded/extra properties
  - Check whether the `width: 100%` uses are needed
- Component JSX (bring classes out into `consts` for consistency with other components)
- Rename classes for valid/helper/error 'bottom-text' to 'sub-text' in markup

title: Implement Modus Progress Bar
description:
The Modus Progress bar is a non-composable component that should include inputs:

- min value (values are whole numbers)
- max value
- value
- color, background color
- display text (if null, display percentage)

It should animate the width of the progress bar on progress change.

https://modus-bootstrap.trimble.com/components/progress/

title: Text Input component improvements
description:
- Fix the issue where the border thickness changes the height of the component when active
- Add a light border around the top, right, left edges
- Add a large size (48px height, 14px font)
- Add a valid state (much like the error state, except green)
- Add helper text (displayed right under the component. Overridden by the valid/error texts.)
- ~Add the active state borders. Only green and red are shown in the Trimble Modus Elements page.~
  - This will be held off until we get a UX review (the details are not clear enough to implement as of now).
- Take full width of its parent?

Reference
https://modus.trimble.com/elements/inputs/

title: Add Text Input validation properties.
Create Alert Component
description:
Create the modus-alert web component using the [Trimble Alert element](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/alerts/) as a guide.

Include unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Spinner Component
description:
Create a modus-spinner component based on the [https://modus.trimble.com/elements/spinners/](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/spinners/)

Include unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Badge Component
description:
Create a badge component in Stencil based on the [Trimble Modus Badge](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/badges/)

Include unit and e2e tests.

title: Create Select Component
description:
Create a web component in Stencil modeled after the Trimble Modus Select.

- Must include a label and error similar to other inputs.
- Should be composable (possibly using modus-list-items).
- Must expose a value attribute for form use.

Include unit and e2e tests.

[Trimble Modus Select](https://modus.trimble.com/elements/inputs/)

title: Move List Item Icon to Slot
description: The list item cannot render modus icons in an external site. The selected icon should be provided via a slot.

title: Test Vertical Slice
description:
Create a local project using the Angular CLI.

The future use cases of this project may an introduction, demonstration, and instructional site for using Modus Web Components.

Pull down the @trimble-oss/modus-web-components NPM package and implement all of the components on a test page.

Bring in the Modus SCSS files to help with colors, typography, and variables.

The major thing to get working is to ensure that our input components like the modus-checkbox and modus-text-input play nicely with Angular Reactive Forms. [This article](https://coryrylan.com/blog/using-web-components-in-angular-forms) may provide some help.
comments: Vertical slice is working, a new story to get devops involved in hosting the site has been created.

title: Cleanup README
description:
The README isn't in a great state to be published in an NPM package.

Things that need work...
- Links to component README files
- Redo the structure to be "consumer first" where the person implementing web components is the primary user

title: Create a Changelog
description:
The file should live at the root of the project and be called "CHANGELOG.md"

Use [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/) as a guide.

Every release should highlight new features, bug fixes, and breaking changes.
comments:
Manually maintaining a CHANGELOG.md could be extra work, but some users may expect to see a CHANGELOG in the project root.

One idea could be to have a CHANGELOG.md with a link to check release notes at: https://github.com/trimble-oss/modus-web-components/releases

title: Publish NPM Package
description:
Publish NPM package to Viewpoint Azure Artifacts.

Publish should happen after a successful build on merge into the trimble-oss/modus-web-components main branch.

Determine the correct configuration for the Stencil compiler and package.json. Publish a tree shakable library with typings.

Keep incrementing the patch version until official release (start at 0.0.1).

Create a web component for the Modus List Item element. This element is used in other components like the dropdown and list.

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

Create a web component for the Modus Dropdown element.

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

title: Create Modus List Component
description:

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

title: Create Modus Text Input Component

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

title: Upgrade @stencil/sass
description:
The @stencil/sass package is currently at version 1.4.1

Puppeteer is currently throwing up warning about @import relating to our use of SASS. The upcoming version 2.0.0 of @stencil/sass is supposed to switch from using @import to @use which may fix this issue.

Once released, upgrade to 2.0.0 or latest above that.
comments: Will close this as package updates are routine with Dependabot now.

title: Enable CI
description:
The project has a linter, unit tests, end to end tests, and a build.

All PRs should run a GitHub action with those steps included before allowing upstream merge.

title: Add ESLint
description: ESLint is the go to JS code linter. Add it to the project and any specific configuration needed to match Viewpoint front-end code best practices and style guide.

title: Configure Prettier
description:
Prettier is installed with Stencil by default. Configure it to match our Viewpoint best practices and guidelines. 

Enable a package.json script to run prettier.

Add instructions to the Getting Started on how to run it and how to enable prettier to run automatically.

-------
@ryan-henness-trimble edit:
We've decided to remove prettier.

title: Update Global SCSS to Latest Modus
description:
The global SCSS files were copied from Modus Bootstrap. They are out of date and do not match Figma. Update the global SCSS values to match Figma as much as possible.

Component specific values will be updated during component creation.
comments: This is really painful to do in one swoop. Instead we'll update the global SCSS files we pulled from Modus Bootstrap as we create components and find problems.

title: Create Modus Checkbox Component
description:
Create a web component for the Modus Checkbox element.

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

title: Create Modus Button Component
description:
Create a web component for the Modus Button element.

Use Figma as the latest spec.

Complete unit and end to end tests.

title: Stencil Dev Site
description:
Stencil comes with a default site rendered from src/index.html for testing components.

Design and update the development site to provide a place to demo and run end to end tests for our web components.
comments: The internal site in Stencil appear more suited for development and end to end testing rather than demo. If we want a demo site in the future I recommend using a SPA framework and installing the bundled component library.
